name: oxymoronic
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
(of two words used together) having, or seeming to have, opposite meanings: Cultural tourism is close to being an oxymoronic phrase. It might sound oxymoronic but there is such a thing as an interesting utility.
More examplesFewer examplesOxymoronic terms such as ‘health clients’ do not convey any meaning when applied to hospital patients.The real line of the state government is the oxymoronic one of “clean coal”.But isn't there something intrinsically oxymoronic about the idea of ethical fashion?Questions about morality and legality in war have an oxymoronic quality – war by its nature involves the suspension of the most fundamental moral injunction, "Thou Shalt Not Kill."
